p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 1.75in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: 0in; text-align: end;
font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 1.75in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: 0in; text-align: end;

div.p:
26/9/68
check that this is 26/9 rather than 26 August as Sara had it for a blind letter entry with this number and a query about the duplication as it a transcribed letter. Printed as 68.09.26a for notes in f/n.

In compliance with your request I have the honor of transmitting to you a verbal translation of the letter, which you were pleased to submit to me for interpretation.
There are two letters attached both dated 19 September 1868. the translation has been written by Ernst Heyne. The letters are by Carl von Mallesch of Beechworth. They are summarised in the Register as: 'He seeks pecuniary assistance, and states he can make suggestions for decrease of lunacy'.

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 1.75in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: 0in;

div.p: I have the honor to be,

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 1.75in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: 0in;
